Definition: In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated by <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You need to determine whether the Head causes the Tail or not, and classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. The crisis causes the focus.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX accepts PersonY invitation<sep>Tail: PersonY smiles
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, there isn't any causal relation between accepting the invitation and smiling. So the output should be"No".
In this example, starvation causes death. Thus, this example should be classified as "Yes".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX accepts the job<sep>Tail: hardworking
Negative Examples.explanation: In this example, there isn't any causal relation between accepting the job and being hardworking. So the output should be "No".
Stress causes fatigue, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: PersonX accepts happily<sep>Tail: to clean up the mess
Head: PersonX accepts PersonY invitation<sep>Tail: PersonX mails an RSVP to PersonY
Head: PersonX accepts PersonY's offer<sep>Tail: personx to accept the offer
Head: PersonX accepts PersonX's diploma<sep>Tail: take final exams
